pros:
* Tend to have a pretty strong focus on work/life balance. Unlimited sick leave, no questions asked about leaving for appointments, things like that. 
* Co-workers are generally pretty nice. People seem to like the work they're doing. 
* Any equipments needs you have are met pretty readily. Software is slightly harder to get a hold of--but can still be done. 
* While pay is not the best, pretty generous bonuses. 
* HP is my first place, but I get the vibe speaking to others that the meeting load is pretty light here. Tend to prioritize people having the time to do their work rather than having them sit in long, pointless meetings.
cons:
* Managers tend to set unrealistic deadlines. They don't expect people to work overtime to meet these deadlines, at least not that I see--but it does lead to a lot of unnecessary shifting and shuffling of schedules. 
* It definitely feels like there's a strong tilt towards male-identifying employees. Would be nice to see more gender diversity in the workplace.

review_title: Depends on what you want in your job
pros: Relatively relaxed environment, flexible hours, easy to switch jobs after a few years.
cons:
Little room for creativity, Large company, lots of corporate BS such as layoffs due to stock price fluctuation, progress is slow. Getting a good manager can make or break your experience. A lot of employees in their early 20s and 45+, but little in between. Get ready to be a powerpoint engineer. Heavily focused on a dying industry (printers) with little drive for innovation. Contractors are treated as second class citizens. HP Corvallis will often layoff engineers and hire them back as contractors for less pay, and they can do this because Corvallis has few other options for engineering jobs. Little respect for computer science and therefore the infrastructure is lacking.
Advice to Management
Pick the best employees for the job, not someone with amazing credentials in general who's experience doesn't fit the position. On the flip side, also hire people if they have the credentials despite them not having an engineering degree. I often heard managers talk about how if a tech wants to be an engineer, they really need to get an engineering degree, despite them having more than enough experience to do the job.
Helpfu

pros: I worked with an excellent team. Top notch professionals. Results oriented, nobody sweated the small stuff. It can be good work while it lasts.
cons:
The corporate environment is cold and abrasive. HR, for example is nonexistent. Everything related to you as an employee is what you see on a website or email. Need to talk to someone about your insurance or paycheck? It's all outsourced if you can even find a number to call. The current environment is one of constant offshoring and divestment in engineering capabilities. Closing down sites, outsourcing development. So sad to see such an amazing collection of talent get scattered to the wind. No hire back policy, so if you do get the short stick and get laid off there is definitely a voted off the island feeling, even though everyone knows it was mandated downsizing and not based on performance.

review_title: A shadow of the old HP
pros:
Accepting, diverse culture
Pockets of wonderful people that want to do well
cons:
Ancient sites feel like graveyards
Desperate low talent middle management trying to hold on (many of the talented managers have moved on)
Finance-oriented executives focused on cost cost cost
Zero innovation except in how to cut costs
A revolving door of low-talent executives passing through and trashing the place, then leaving with big payouts
Off-shoring jobs to lowest cost places 
Ancient product line with no desire to innovate - unless you are developing ways to charge people more for less
Horrible all day and all night hours training people in other countries to take your job.
Disheartening to see how highly paid executives are for the little innovation and business results they deliver
A harsh environment where providing feedback to management is absolutely not appreciated
Advice to Management
Enjoy it while you have it... you're on the Kodak track.

pros: Diversity, inclusion, social office in Rio Rancho, team oriented employees to help you. There aren't many helicopter managers, allowing for freedom to work how you want to work. Relatively relaxed environment; lots of time to be social in between email tasks.
cons:
Trainings are out dated and need updating to educate and correctly onboard. The gender wage gap is 100% real (same degree, experience, job title results in a difference in $10k in salary gap between men and women). Compensation for commission is a mess; at times, pay out for sales commissions don't hit your account for 3 to 6 months after sale is completed. When management asks sales how to improve strategies/tools/processes, the common response to any suggestion outside of what they want to hear is "there's nothing we can do ," all the way up to director level. This site and the teams within just float, lacking any initiative to propel themselves forward, design anything new, etc. Toxic work environment, full of gossip and teenager mentalities; your manager won't watch the clock but your peers will on their behalf. The environment is a little better in a WFH scenario. Half of the W2s received from this company have been wrong and needed to be updated before I could file for taxes.
Helpfu

review_title: I thought that's where i was going to retire
pros:
Company car with gas card 
Traveling to a lot of places for work
Co workers were all very nice and helpful people
The equipment i worked on was Engineered very well
Documentation is by far the best I've seen at any major or minor industry leaders. That's in ease of use, designed well (service manuals, installation manuals, user manuals), and not scattered around in different websites or cloud drives. 
No pre employment drug test or any I've ever heard of
Company credit card for travel expenses
cons:
Management are the good Ole boys club and if you're not in it you're nothing. 
They don't give you pay raises when they give your a promotion in Engineer Levels. Only from Service Engineer to Service Specialist. 
You have to pay for your company car. 150$ a month. Every other company I've worked for this is free of charge and you still get to drive it for personal use. 
Bi-monthly pay
Traveling for work isn't all is cracked up to be quite a lot.
Advice to Management
Stick up for your employees
Let your employees question things. Don't think they are being uncooperative. We can all learn something by communicating.
Learn what your employees actually do for you or if you don't know and are unwilling to learn then don't think you know what is best for how to do their jobs.

review_title: Good work/life balance, low salary, concerning trajectory
pros: HP Boise had great employee groups(I loved participating in the Young Employees Network and Volleyball leagues). The work/life balance is generally good as you'll find the parking lots mostly empty by 6. The overall engineering culture is still quite good, especially if you get on a team working on a new exciting project.
cons:
Unfortunately, there are quite a few reasons why I wouldn't recommend pursuing a job at HP right now.

There have been significant layoffs with various teams in the past few years. The company claims it's invested in Boise yet the headcount has been on a steady march downward. The high-end firmware, low-end firmware, and cloud(Roam) engineering teams have been gutted at various points, with work moving to Vancouver, India("the Hub"), or Korea(ex-Samsung). This has also led to significant attrition of top talent. Of my entire "generation"(5-10 years), almost everyone I know has left.

Simply put, you won't get the best salary at HP. Comparing salary notes with former coworkers, you can expect a 25-30% better salary with other companies in the area(Intuit, Cradlepoint, Kount, Micron, etc). 

The overall direction of the company is perpetually depressing. Let's face it -- printing is not a growing business nor will it be in the future. The trend is that every quarter the financials are either flat or declining. HP has already saturated the printer market. If you're not getting a great salary, why work somewhere that's on the decline?
Advice to Management
Honestly, it didn't feel like senior management was "on our side."
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
Honestly, it didn't feel like senior management was "on our side."
Helpfu

pros: Good benefits and reasonable compensation
cons:
Dirty politics; excessive work hours and no work/life balance; little opportunities for advancement; gender inequity
Advice to Management
HP is not the company it pretends to be. To management: Look in the mirror, honestly see yourself as a company and either make the needed changes so the reflection is accurate, or tell people who and what HP really has become. 

This is especially true in the PC division, where 6-day work weeks with 12-14 hour workdays are common and ongoing. Endless slides and presentations go in circles and do not move the business forward. The politics are dirty and I've never seen such backbiting among employees, mostly out of fear. Maslow's hierarchy being what it is, people spend an inordinate amount of time managing up, sometimes claiming credit for ideas that aren't theirs. I have seen a large degradation of integrity and Open Door most certainly is dead. 

There has been little true innovation in some time, which is not surprising in these circumstances. The quality of HP products has been on a steady decline and I believe this is linked to the degradation of the culture and values. At some point, it is going to show in the products. I was stunned - in recently looking for a new AIO laser monochrome printer - to find HP way down the Consumer Reports list, at #12. 

The pay is fine and benefits are good, but there is little opportunity for advancement and work/life balance is non-existent. HP talks a good talk about diversity and I believe is really trying to bring in a diverse set of people, but it is only "skin-deep" without inclusion. By this, I mean a company may hire more people of color and more women, but once they're hired they have to conform to a certain cultural norm - a white, male, corporate culture norm. Cultural and style differences are suppressed to fit in. So no, you can't remotely bring your whole self to work, just pieces. I realize this is a very difficult hurdle and challenge, but HP pretends that it's achieved inclusion, when that is not the case. Again, time for an honest assessment in front of that mirror. 

Oddly, there is a strong bias against the Boise site and Boise employees. This was expressed by Carly Fiorina, when she mentioned roadkill in association with her trip to Boise, and many times since by people from other sites who seemed to think Boiseans were lazy and not very intelligent. Boise is home of the LaserJet, on whose coattails the company rode for a very long time. There are so many brilliant people at HP in Boise because that is where they want to live, not because that's where they could get a job. Writing this as someone with an Ivy League undergrad and high honors MBA from a top 10 US business school who could - and has - worked elsewhere but chose Boise for my home, that is narrow-minded and just plain...stupid. I have seen that unfounded bias grow in recent years. Inclusion, anyone?

I left for a position with another company, where I have found the differences striking. My creativity has powerfully re-awakened, my work is appreciated and I honestly love my job. To any job seekers reading this, please be careful and thoughtful about where you go to work, and I wish you all the best. You have a unique contribution to make in this world.
Helpfu

review_title: THANKS HP! Now I understand why corporations are the enemy of the common worker.
pros: people, some office perks, not much
cons:
Managers are selected for any other reason but what they contribute to their team. I saw three managers all get hired for either quotas, career brownie points, or because they were friends with the director. All lasted less than a year before being fired and a lot of people quit off of those teams that were competent employees. You also run into a culture where people don't care to work hard, it is easy to hide within the corporate conglomerate without contributing to the bottom line. There are a lot of egos at play and office politics is expected, you have to kiss butt to get ahead, certainly not a meritocracy. Also, and this is HUGE, they don't like to pay their employees in a timely fashion or accurately.
Advice to Management
Take your own advice when dealing with internal problems, lip service doesn't help anyone in the end. I suppose that just helps to keep the lies going and nothing really changes because it is all disingenuous. Also, probably shouldn't violate compensation laws of your employees, definitely not a good thing, even if you are "woke" HP.m Most people would rather be paid in accurately and in a timely manner than anything else.
Helpfu

pros: Gain solid UX background and skill set with the stability of working for a company that is an industry giant. Large design teams let’s you become very specialized in your expertise area and really learn and grow. The design team itself is a class-act. You’d be hard-pressed to find a better team of talent who treat each other like family.
cons:
The “machine” can be difficult to influence-a big company like HP is not agile in how it responds to industry trends. Good, solid people managers there are hard to find. Most are self promoters who are great at managing up but fail at empowering their teams. No raises - none. Go in string ad Be sure you negotiate salary correctly from the beginning because raises are few and tiny.
Advice to Management
A people managers main role is to ensure their team has what they need in order to be successful. You should spend your time removing the barriers your team faces and empowering each person to learn and grow. A people manager is not “above” an individual contributor and should never view the structure like this. Managing “up” is really bad form and reveals your agenda if you have one.

review_title: Employee Caliber (including the CEO) - Not as it Used to Be
pros: The company is socially responsible and truly cares about social issues and human welfare. A well recognized brand with ongoing, consistent sales training
cons:
Job descriptions today have lower overall requirements than the identical role demanded several years ago and salaries are lower than the average. If you're of the mindset that starting at a lower overall salary and working hard to build your reputation will set you up for an extraordinary, long-term career, you could be disappointed. 

HP values their shareholders. Lower wages across every category became a priority when former CEO Meg Whitman recognized that the company was an inverted pyramid, rather than a conventional pyramid - with fewer people at the bottom than near the top. 

The average wage in each category today is less than the same position paid in 1990. If you stay in a job role long enough to be at the top of the position's salary band, its very likely your job will be eliminated in 18 months or less.

You may also endure "penalty for performance". Quotas are not based on averages or pipeline likelihood but rather on the last six months plus management's agreed growth percentage - e.g., if you have a rockstar fiscal half, your next quota will be set at the record breaking sum plus an increased 9-15%. The reality penalty is virtually zero commission and an unattainable quota, leaving your employment stability vulnerable. 

There are only 500 Fortune 500 companies - beware if you have the "good fortune" of closing a double digit, multi-million dollar purchase. A closed "special hardware project" in one fiscal half on paper becomes the expected run rate computer hardware expectation.
Advice to Management
365 performance reviews are a good idea. My manager used input from my peers in my reviews where he had knowledge gaps. It would also be beneficial to use this review style to include team insights from team subordinates to grow management. 

Quotas need to be satisfying and demand challenge, however penalty for performance can be avoided when quotas are grounded in business intelligence, rather than last half number plus a growth %. Growth could be measured by new logos with business taken from the competition and run rate with new category adds and new product lines of business.
Helpful (2
advice_to_mgmt:
365 performance reviews are a good idea. My manager used input from my peers in my reviews where he had knowledge gaps. It would also be beneficial to use this review style to include team insights from team subordinates to grow management. 

Quotas need to be satisfying and demand challenge, however penalty for performance can be avoided when quotas are grounded in business intelligence, rather than last half number plus a growth %. Growth could be measured by new logos with business taken from the competition and run rate with new category adds and new product lines of business.

review_title: The utmost collegial company with pros & cons, but overall a great company
pros:
1. Culture: Extremely collegial, very little politics and the political people get weeded out (much more so than half a dozen other Fortune 500s for whom I’ve worked)
2. International: Substantial international exposure opportunities to work with, or live in
3. Employee Development: Invest significantly in employees (e.g., Stanford program)
4. Pay: Decent salary (though not on high side in Silicon Valley, stock units should be higher Valley)
5. Career Path Opportunity Coming: Big opportunity coming to rise ranks given heavy generational weighting towards Boomers and a huge gap in Gen X’ers to manage the company when the Boomers retire (although they all seem to be hanging on longer than expected)
6. Management Team: I was almost always impressed by the calm, intelligent, non-arrogant nature of the Executives...the jerks got weeded out pretty quickly
cons:
1. Title Deflation: many people are doing the work of one level above their title given how many business units under business units there are across company 
2. Limited Career Path in Short Term (for Gen X’ers): until the top heavy Boomers really start leaving, but then there will be a huge vacuum of talent missing 
3. Mgmt. by Committee: Occasional downside of collegial culture, too many meetings to make decisions by committee
4. Late Cycle Industries/No Growth: Print is the money maker and it’s on a secular decline that 3D printing can’t make up for quick enough, and PCs can’t cover from a margin POV...it’s gonna take time to ever become a growth company again
Advice to Management
- Ensure the middle generation of top talent (Gen X) sees a path forward. I was on fast track up through Director, but left because the path wasn’t clear and it was taking far too long
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
- Ensure the middle generation of top talent (Gen X) sees a path forward. I was on fast track up through Director, but left because the path wasn’t clear and it was taking far too long

review_title: A good company. Not a great company
pros:
Open to flexible/remote employment (but less so now than in the past)
Not a dog-eat-dog environment.
Ethical and cares about hearing the voice of the worker.
cons:
No stock unless you're a manger - does nothing to retain top talent.
Stingy company. Squeak when you walk budgets. Even travel is rare.
They always want to hear your voice, but nothing ever seems to change.
Advice to Management
HP is a slave to its high margin Supplies business and they have been unwilling to disrupt it - even a little. They have been so slow and unwilling to disrupt it that they would not budget properly to sell printers. And what happens when you don't sell low margin printers today? Yes, you guessed it. You don't sell high margin supplies tomorrow. And now those chickens have come home to roost. Layoffs of 7k-9k employees most likely on the print side coming in the next couple of years. HP has lost its way by hanging on to the old way of doing things. They don't innovate nor do they do what it takes to retain top talent. Fresh young talent is not offered stock. Get those golden handcuffs out, HP. Make it rewarding to stay and hard to leave. But without stock, anyone can be tempted to leave for nothing more than extra pay because we don't have to give up anything to go. By giving stock to everyone you will make it a lot harder to leave. These things should be obvious but only make HP look cheap. That's why HP is nothing more than a good company, not a great company.

review_title: Good people, stagnant thinking, uncompetitive salary and benefits
pros: It’s surprising when you run into some very sharp people working at a stagnant legacy tech company, but really, there are very good people to work with at HP.
cons:
For a company that has focused on essentially 2 things forever, it’s unsurprising that change is hard. However, with all the profit printing cartridges have rung up over the years, HP management and CTO really failed to ever invest in the “next business.” 3D print may become a good business over time, but it cannot be the only business. For a company that has the muscle and makeup for building hardware, HP has been inept at acquiring or home-growing any growth businesses.
Advice to Management
You have to make some calculated bets. 2D print is not going to return the same revenue and profit over the next 10+ years that it used to. Acquire a complementary hardware company in a growth area - is it a POS company, a media streaming company, an IOT play... I don’t know, but I’m hoping you do. Whatever you do, don’t go for anymore value plays - I.e., a company on the decline - palm was a garbage buy, Samsung laser printer business was mediocre. Be bold, be creative, let’s gamble now while we still have the chips rather than just die a slow death by 1000 tiny cuts.

Also, you really need to take a hard look at your management. People unwilling to change, stuck on the old ways, wanting to play it safe, cut them. Complacency is a slow-growing but fatal cancer that will kill a company. HP still has time, but that window is closing. Changing business structures isn’t addressing the issues, it is just kicking the can down the road.
Helpful (2

review_title: You’ll be just another cog in the gargantuan HP machine
pros:
1. People. Coworkers were almost always great. 

2. Flexibility of work schedule. WFH and flexibility in working hours was great. 

3. Pay. I’ve yet to get a job that pays me even 64% if what I made at HP. 

4. Benefits Package. (PTO + insurance + retirement)

5. Company-provided equipment. (Laptops, monitors, etc) 

6. Empathy and compassion from management (depending upon your individual manager) if something tragic or traumatic happens. After the death of a parent, my boss let me take four weeks of paid bereavement leave that didn’t come out of my PTO balance.
cons:
1. The culture created by management. You’re just a cog in the gargantuan HP machine. HP cares not about your hopes and dreams or your career advancement. Even if you push hard for something like mentorship, which is something they promote, your requests will likely be ignored or pushed aside. 

2. Adherence to the bottom line creates job instability for employees. Sudden and unexpected layoff occur. I was “let go” and given fake reasons why. What it came down to was that I was laid off without HP calling it a lay-off so they didn’t have to report it, which would have been detrimental to the stock price. 

3. If you get laid off or let go, you won’t see it coming. I had a one-on-one scheduled with my manager. As we were walking to find a conference room, we chatted like it was any other day. Just chitchat. Then we walked into a conference room in a different building and he immediately hit me with the news I was being let go. When I questioned why, he gave me a made up reason related to my performance. When I challenged him and told me he was incorrect, he fumbled over his words and gave me a different reason that was equally made up. 

4. Lack of interaction with management. In the nearly five years I worked at HP, I can probably count on two hands the number of times I had real interaction (something beyond chitchat) with the two different managers for whom I worked. 

5. Also, if you accept a severance package, as I did, you will never be eligible for rehire. EVER. After working for HP for 4 years and just shy of 11 months, my severance package was a half a month’s pay, but no one ever told me I’d never be able to come back and my severance paperwork never indicated as much, either. 

6. Favoritism. This is definitely a problem. My first manager took the words of another person I worked with as the God’s honest truth when that person blamed me for a mistake she made. My manager never even asked me if I knew anything about the problem created by this other person. She just automatically assumed the problem arose because of me. I was told “you set us back weeks” after this other person mucked up some data she was analyzing for a new metric. This other person had asked me to look at the data and run a test, which I did exactly as she asked me to. I ran the test on literally 100 rows out of 100,000 rows for approximately 15 minutes and didn’t save anything. My second manager played favorites and I felt as if I had been “left behind” (for lack of a better term) while the other new hires I worked with were brought along much more quickly than I was. The other two new people on the team were given special treatment and paid special attention that I wasn’t. It helped if you were an athlete of some kind or if you liked mountain biking. That helped you “fit in” with the little clique created by my manager. Apparently I didn’t “fit in” because I didn’t join them on their mountain biking trek or their whitewater rafting trip one summer.
Advice to Management
Shift a lot of your focus from stakeholders to employees. You’ll be more successful in the long run. Open the lines of communication and help employees achieve success.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
Shift a lot of your focus from stakeholders to employees. You’ll be more successful in the long run. Open the lines of communication and help employees achieve success.
Helpfu

review_title: The right priorities, healthy culture, strong leadership
pros:
-HP is full of tremendously talented people who are genuinely committed to each other's growth and success. It's a culture that puts people first and leads with integrity, humility, and empathy. 
-The work is meaningful and just the right level of challenging. 
-Frequent constructive feedback on performance. Growth mindset is taking hold across the organization, emphasizing the importance of continuous growth, taking risks, and figuring stuff out. 
-Employees are recognized and rewarded not only for what we do, but how we do it. Getting results is important, but not at the expense of our core values or business priorities. 
-Boundless opportunities to stretch into new areas, take on new responsibilities, and explore potential career paths. 
-The executive leadership team is clear about expectations, shares information with transparency, holds themselves accountable for results, and works to make sure employees have what they need to be successful. 
-Companywide commitment to sustainability, diversity & inclusion, and learning & development is inspiring and demonstrates that HP wants to be more than a financially successful enterprise. It's a company with purpose and a heart out to improve lives and communities.
cons:
-Strong bias toward collaboration can gum up the decision-making process. 
-Some senior managers focus too much on managing tactical details rather than ensuring alignment with strategic vision and goals.
Advice to Management
-Identify and retain our strong talent. 
-Recruit and hire the next generation of technical gurus. Maintain HP's emphasis on meaningful innovation. 
-Strongly encourage and empower faster decision-making among employees beneath middle to upper management.

review_title: Good & Bad- Culture is changing in 2019
pros: HP Inc has a history of being a great place to work. They pay well, they offer a competitive commission structure, good benefits and typically good management who care about their employees. I enjoy the job although it is extremely challenging. Diversity is a perk.
cons:
Commission structure and reporting are muddy (very unclear). They can take back commission paychecks at any time, for any reason and it's hard to prove they are wrong. Upper management seems to be extremely stern and only care about numbers and bottom line. They are still laying off employees with work force reductions for no rhyme or reason other than getting rid of management other upper management does not like on a personal level. I am always afraid I will lose my job. This is not a company to work for long-term as most of the 25-30+ year employees are laid off at the drop of the hat for being too expensive in favor of hiring on low-cost college grad's.
Advice to Management
Stop with the work force reductions, go back to a culture of managers who care about employees. Outwardly we are focusing on women's rights and diversity + inclusion but inwardly management is cutting out women from leadership with work force reductions and re-organizations.
Helpfu

Stop with the work force reductions, go back to a culture of managers who care about employees. Outwardly we are focusing on women's rights and diversity + inclusion but inwardly management is cutting out women from leadership with work force reductions and re-organizations.

pros: Flexible hours; average tech salary; benefits
cons:
During my tenure at HP Inc.'s Vancouver office, I witnessed increasingly poor quality of employees and behavior that ended up making this the worst workplace I have been a part of. Although tolerable at first, it seemed like a variety of antisocial behaviors and ongoing harassment were commonplace and becoming worse to the point where I developed serious concerns with the ethics of the company. Based on my experiences towards the end I can't recommend anyone work for this company or support HP Inc. in any way, especially if you are differently-abled. I would not feel at all safe allowing my child to be an intern at the site I worked at and it scares me that people as young as high school age were being exposed to this environment. 

The workplace itself could be described as dingy, crowded, and cluttered which did nothing to help the generally poor environment. HP seems to have fully bought into the idea of a temporary workforce and what seemed like constant restructuring and employment thrash made this a particularly soulless place to be. The best, most talented, and generally nicest people tended to do their time and leave, to be replaced with ever-poorer quality people in a depressing race to the bottom.
Advice to Management
Make some token effort to hire decent people. Enforce the employee handbook, code of conduct, and the law of each site's jurisdiction.
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: Make some token effort to hire decent people. Enforce the employee handbook, code of conduct, and the law of each site's jurisdiction.

review_title: Current Iteration of HP (not HPE) has a great ethic and culture
pros: First, it's nice to be in a leading company in an interesting industry that is culturally relevant. Culture is very supportive and cognizant of inclusion and recognition. They also treat you like an adult, and as long as you get your work done nobody is really clock-watching and you have flexibility to manage personal needs with business ones. I'm an old timer, going back to the Compaq days, and the current work environment is the best I have experienced in my 20+ years with the company.
cons:
No macro level cons, but as I am sure it is with any company, an individual job or role can have drawbacks: Some require extensive travel, since we are an international company some require calls at very odd hours, emergencies regarding product quality or supply issues can break out which can translate to very intense periods of long days until the situation is resolved. I'm sure there are some turd managers here and there, but from what I have seen they are not tolerated very long and get sorted out. But there are no overall "Company Cons" that come to mind (and keep in mind, I am an old Coot and usually pretty cynical, so for me to be this positive says something!).
Advice to Management
Keep up the good work. Appreciate and support the movement to try to bring younger talent in the company, but be sure to continue to value and recognize wisdom and experience of your experienced employees. I would say challenge your mindset on what business we are in....it should not be viewed as the "printers and computers" business....we are in the "image and information" business and so developing new products/services/opportunities should flow from that mindset(e.g. people haven't stopped printing as many pictures...people have new ways to view images. There are more new images created now than ever before...what can we do to make these accessible to people?). It is like the old standard that people don't buy drills, they buy the ability to make holes.
Helpfu

review_title: When its good, its good. When its bad, its bad.
pros:
A strong desire for fairness and encouraging teamwork. Also, working around some very talented people encourages growth. For newer employess, HP can be a great learning opportunity working alongside these veterans. After about five years, it is usually time to move on to another company where you can have some assurance of more steady career paths.

Upper management strives to provide solid financial stability to the company.
cons:
Upper management treats the workforce as interchangeable cost units that can be moved from country to country. This means that you can be layed off (WFR) at a moments notice regardless of how talented or how much you contribute to the company. The depersonalization is such that people are not really called people by management they are called TCOW's(total cost of workforce -- permanent) and RCOW's (resource cost of workforce -- contractors). When the word comes down from on high to cut your TCOWs you have to do so regardless of how good the people are that are working for you. As you read the reviews you will notice a very different set of reviews depending which country the review is from.

Management creates quite a bit of PR about how they value talent within HP, but the lack of training and/or apprenticeship opportunities to develop people into new or changing roles is almost non-existent. It is pretty much limited to the occasional quarterly class on management processes or access to Linked-In learning. There is tuition reimbursement but it takes a serious commitment to a program before you can use it.

It is clear that the stock holders greatly out-prioritize the work force.
Advice to Management
Start treating people as people again and not generic cost units.
Helpful (6
advice_to_mgmt: Start treating people as people again and not generic cost units.

The Executive Leadership team is committed to sustainability and diversity & inclusion and they have objectives that measure their progress on these issues, in addition to their business objectives. pros: Great CEO, a very inspiring speaker, and a good top management team. I really enjoyed their vision and presentation skills. Competitive salary, good benefits. Free coffee machine.
cons:
Old garage office atmosphere. Printer parts everywhere, old dirty carpets, layers of dust. Hardly any natural light. Work life balance is a joke, I was expected to be in my seat 8 hours a day, every day. Hiring process was a joke as well. They were hiring a number, not an individual. None of my references were called. I didn't meet a single team member nor my future manager during the interview. Highly hierarchical management structure. It'll take years to see the light. Workaholics would do well there. I met a few pearls of wisdom surrounded by dark waters of age and complexity. Clans of old timers make team work more difficult than it should be. Good ideas get buried within complexities of habitual tendencies. If you are looking for a healthy work-life balance within a high energy environment, look someplace else, or at least insist on meeting your team and seeing your future office during the interview.

review_title: Had a great experience with HPI
pros: HP was a major employer for many years. I really enjoyed the traditional HP close nit environment and I absolutely loved how HP allowed me to have a work/life balance. I had a great experience working for HP for 25+ years
cons:
Years ago, in order to remain competitive, HP started to act like many similar tech companies. That included changes in benefits as well as profit sharing. Eventually, just like many companies, HP had many layoffs. The many layoffs caused a lot of stress. Unfortunately, being just like other companies made it difficult for employees to set HP apart from other companies...and that can impact employee loyalty.
Advice to Management
Find a way to stand out from other tech companies that will increase employee loyalty.

review_title: Great company while you are needed. Outsourcing is a problem.
pros:
Large, stable company with good benefits.
Volunteer programs / Classes / Employee events
Flexible work environments
cons:
HP has shown an increasing inclination towards outsourcing work to 3rd party houses or their China campus. Many jobs are being sent overseas while qualified Americans are being caught up in "workforce reductions".
There is no stability in HP. In the 10 years I was there I went through multiple restructures and mass layoffs. HP has a tendency to alternate between contracted labor and permanent employees with layoffs in between. 
If you are contract, be aware there is a forced 3 week unpaid shutdown during Christmas.
If you are perm, be aware that if you are caught up in one of HP's workforce reductions, there is a strict no-rehire policy. In my case, HP just purchased a new campus in Spring TX and was preparing to move to the new building. We were all assigned desks and I actually bought a house and moved my family closer to the new campus. Two weeks before the building move a large group of us were "reduced". We had all been given excellent reviews, the budget seemed fine, and the reason given was a need to "refresh the talent pool". We were given a severance package and 60 days (during a forced holiday shutdown) to find a job within the company. Since most of us were unable to obtain new positions that quickly especially during a forced shutdown, we are no longer able to work at HP either as contractors or permanent employees with no timeline restrictions. Take caution if moving your family!
Advice to Management
HP is an American company that should invest primarily in supporting the American workforce. Please do not continue to send jobs overseas just to reduce the bottom line. We keep hearing about how great HP is doing as far as market share and finances but so many jobs that could be filled locally are not, all for the sake of the budget. 
I would also suggest reviewing the post-WFR no-rehire policy, especially considering HP's campus move to a much less central to Houston location.
Helpful (6

review_title: No career development, no raises, no investing in R&D. The company is falling
pros: Nothing good at all at HP
cons:
Printing and PCs are dead. The business is falling apart. Management only makes numbers look good using layoffs and cost reduction.
Deadlines are tight, scope is high and resources are low. There is no development at all. One has to wait over 15 years to get a promotion and salary raises are below 3% at best. 
A lot of experienced employee are complacent because they won’t get fired. They don’t add value to the teams and get away with doing the minimum. They know HP will pay everyone the same regardless of performance so why bother working hard? This leaves 1-2 people from the team doing most of the work until they burn and leave to go elsewhere
Advice to Management
Invest more than 2.4% in R&D rather than wasting money on paying so much to CEO and executives

review_title: The HP way died over a decade ago!
pros: While they were on their game (pre 2001) they were among the best companies to work for.
cons:
...the HP way started to dwindle with the hiring of Carly Fiorina at the beginning of the 21st century and finally died with the Compaq merger in 2001. At the same time, Carly’s NEW “HP Invent” initiated what it called its Work Force Restructuring (WFR) initiative wherein thousands of HP employees, some with decades of service, were LET GO. From this point on, Monday morning WFR’s became part of the New HP Invent! HP also started outsourcing most of their U.S. Workforce during this period to lower cost labor mills over-seas. Anyone who still thinks HP is relevant needs to put the Kool-Aid down and get it together. Go get a good paying modern job with a sustainable company already!
Advice to Management
...you know who you are and the fate that awaits you. You had the time of your life WFR'ing people and now, it's your turn to take the walk of shame!
Helpful (2
advice_to_mgmt: ...you know who you are and the fate that awaits you. You had the time of your life WFR'ing people and now, it's your turn to take the walk of shame!

review_title: A career at HP Inc. - no reason to go elsewhere
pros:
The people you work with are talented, creative, and willing to collaborate.
Flexible work hours enable a better work life balance
The content is technically challenging and everybody wants to do it right.
Attrition is low because people tend to join and stick around.
cons:
While pay isn't as competitive as it use to be it is still among the best. Long timers and new hires seem to be in the best shape. The middle is squeezed.
Workforce growth and turnover are low so growth opportunities aren't as good as they use to be.
Too many contractors, HP seems to be reluctant to hire (good and bad)
Advice to Management
Keep it up, the last few years will hopefully help return HP to what it once was. A great growth story.

review_title: HP Inc ... great place to work
pros: Management showing they appreciate people, not just profits-- looking out for customer, and employee, as well as stakeholder. And, lots of really smart & friendly people who work here... and many "HP lifers" who work to uphold the culture (help return it to the culture of Bill & Dave?). As well as an influx of young employees, keeping our approach fresh and infusing the culture with good energy.
cons:

review_title: Wish I could have joined earlier!

You work a lot, but the work is enjoyable and satisfying. Healthy sense of urgency, no complacency in this organization!
cons:
Short-term focus on this week's / this month's results. Probably not too different compared to other major corporations, but you need to build the business a bit more for the longer term.

review_title: Stressful work builds strong employee bonds
pros: As always, the best part about working at HP is the chance to work with SOOO many incredibly talented and genuine people. I have truly formed an HP family.
cons:
The job is pretty stressful and demanding on my time. I work with colleagues and suppliers in Asia and Europe so I work all day at the office and most evenings at home on calls and meetings. I do have flexible hours so I generally choose which 12-15 hours I want to work. Also, due to time zones, my work tends to start Sunday evenings and run through Friday. Vacations are a joke, if I don't work at least 1/2 days on vacation then I get so far behind I spend the next several weeks digging out of email overload.
Advice to Management
Find ways to allow the employees to have a real work/life balance and set boundaries. Work/life balance is part of our culture but not a reality for many if not most employees.
Helpfu

review_title: HP Inc. Corvallis, OR is a great place to work.
pros:
1. Great support for work-life balance up the entire management chain, especially for new parents. 
2. Good benefits, good compensation. 
3. Great people to work with and for, from top to bottom. 
4. Great place to start for those fresh out of school. 
5. Great support for career development and advancement for those willing to rise to the challenge. 
6. Great support network for veterans and reservists, even if pulled to active duty. 
7. Due to overall environment on-site, I look forward to coming to work knowing that I will enjoy discovering solutions to challenges with incredible coworkers and friends.
cons:
1. Would personally prefer more emphasis on salary than bonuses, as I'm invested in HP for long term career. 
2. Would like to see salary boosts for the long time faithful employees due to newer employees being hired at the same or higher pay level.
Advice to Management
Benefits, Recognitions, etc. are nice, but as we engage our lives and careers in supporting HP's current and future goals, it would be nice if HP demonstrated that their employees are more important than stockholders and likewise invested in their ability to better support our families by placing emphasis on improved Salaries. i.e., take them from good to great.
Helpfu

pros:
The culture at HP is by far the best part of working here. People are very friendly and collaborative, and the organization is flat and egalitarian. "Cut throat" isn't in our vocabulary, and people exhibiting that style don't seem to last here.

It's also nice to work for a company that truly values diversity and not just because it's an industry trend.

HP also provides a lot of benefits and services to their employees, including free on-site health screenings during the work day. The local sites also hold a ton of social and fun events throughout the year.
cons:
HP pays at the median for the industry, and the pathways for salary advancement are unclear. So, while the work is engaging and the benefits are good, many employees are lured away to other tech companies that pay better.

HP is a pretty lean organization, which introduces the side effect of not being able to move up the leadership ladder easily. I don't know that I'll have the career advancement opportunities I'm looking for unless the right person leaves.
Advice to Management
HP is a great place to work, but we will need to pay above the industry average to attract and keep the best talent.
Helpfu

HP is a great place to work, but we will need to pay above the industry average to attract and keep the best talent.

cons:

This is not necessarily a down-side, but this company is not for those, who are not self-motivated. The work is done in very open/modern environments, which foster collaboration, but because of this there is not a lot of privacy. Again, not necessarily a downside, just something to consider.

review_title: Great place for high performers to gain experience in many different areas
pros: I have been able to move around 7 different roles in 3 countries over 11 years in HP Inc. From product quality, to sales transformation, to eCommerce, Wearables Incubation and CTO Vision team. If you are confident, perform well and seek out new challenges, HP Inc brings amazing career opportunities. I have been paid well and Managers get a generous bonus (based on company performance)
cons:
Pockets of HP can have a lot of politics, where it is more important to make sure people are happy than to get your job done. Most of the managers I have had have been poor at giving constructive feedback on growth opportunities for my career.
Advice to Management
If you assign one person a goal but hold another person accountable - that is what causes politics. It is not usual to see it in the sales teams (they have clear goals) the BUs, Ops and Labs teams have these problems, depending on the leader. More coaching from HR experts on how managers should set and track goals would help - it varies a lot and HR is too under resources to assist at the moment.

pros: Working along some very sharp people. For the most part there is a strong sense of commitment and teamwork. Also, for the motivated, there are opportunities to do different things and in fact management encourages moving around between various job disciplines. Since the takeover by Dion, the commitment to making very friendly and exciting products has escalated.
cons:
Strategy to drive all work possible to offshore locations. Unfortunately, this increases the stress to onshore people who have to mentor and train the offshore labor. It is very hard to take ownership for an extremely interesting project without it being fractured across timezones. The result is a very exhausting schedule between daytime and nighttime meetings. It is not uncommon to have a 14 hour start to finish day (with gaps in the middle).

The office environment is subpar compared to the competition. People are packed 4/quad and there is absolutely no privacy and ability to focus on work without using noise cancelling headphones. Fortunately, there is some flexibility to work from home which can give you a better focus environment.
Advice to Management
Stop offshoring so aggressively. You are saving money on the expense report, but you are discouraging and stressing out the lead innovators in the company. Many have left over the last few years because of this stress.

review_title: Ability to have a flexible schedule at HP Inc. is outstanding
pros:
1. Flexible schedule: no questions asked. No need to miss kids' sporting events, no worries when having to pick up a sick child from school. HP supports working from home when necessary. An atmosphere of trust, get your work done and no one will look over your shoulder noting when you arrive and leave.
2. There are plenty of opportunities for on-site recreational activities such as soccer, ultimate Frisbee, yoga and Virgin Pulse fitness programs and challenges. HP'ers are fitness-minded and value the lunch-time exercise opportunities.
3. There are opportunities to move around within HP to perform different job functions. Easy networking = more job opportunities
4. Innovative products are being developed, e.g. 3D printers
cons:
1. Work to ensure raises & bonuses are reflective of one's workload and performance, in a group that is competing for the same lump sum of money.
2. HP could do some basic research on how truly terrible the MetLife dental benefits are and how many claims are denied at first and then after 6 months of arguing, the claim is processed. HP should not offer employees such a terrible insurance option.
Advice to Management
If managers are not having 1:1s with their team members regularly, it is tough for a manager to really know and compare the workload and performance of each team member. We all compete for the same lump sum of money for raises and bonuses. If the manager is not involved and thinks "the less I hear from my team members, the better," they are not well equipped to dole out the raises and bonuses. This leads to dissatisfaction if you think your raise or bonus was mediocre compared to your workload and job performance.
Helpfu

Helpful
HP Inc. Response
April 26, 2018 – Global Social Media Coordinator
Thank you for sharing your impressions about working at HP. Responding to your comments about compensation, I want to assure you that we continuously benchmark job and location data for our employment markets in order to offer competitive, market-based pay packages to our employees around the globe. We also give guidelines and training to our managers for administering pay in a way that aligns pay and performance so that employees can share in the success they help create. At HP, total rewards includes more than just your paycheck. It includes a number of programs that fit together. We take the spirit of reinvention to heart, and we continuously review and adjust our total rewards package, including benefits and pay, based on employee feedback and competitiveness. That said, your candid feedback is helpful and appreciated

pros: Work life balance is good. Most the time you can get away with 35 - 45 hours a week. People are generally good and friendly. There is no yelling and throwing at people. Benefits are good: 17 Days a vacation starting out is nice. 4% 401K match, Tuition reimbursement program, College debut assistance, 4 hours of volunteering a month. We have lots of clubs at the Vancouver site. We have four person pods instead of grey cubes. There is plenty of decorations and self expression around. Tools and processes are getting improved. 5% discount on stock purchase. A lot of people here are life long employees with 20 years plus at HP. Parents and their kids work here, and people even marry coworkers!
cons:
Pay is low and promotions are hard to come by. You will get small 2% raise every-other year and bonus. It all depends on company performance, and how much funds your team is given. If you are in a good performing team and your manager is given money then you will have no problem getting a 4% raise each year, but it is really all out of your control. Ineffective and incompetent people are not fired. There are a fair amount of lazy people that are just coasting here. That said there are some bright people here but they are few and far between. Upper management is incompetent and comes up with stupid project ideas that you have to implement against your better judgment. We used to have various year round celebrations but management cut those back. There is really no career growth potential unless you want to grind out 10 years. Once you pass entry and intermediate you land into the career plateau knows as specialist. It will take five years to get to the next career ranking, unless you leave and come back like so many do. On top of that, every 18 months or so is a company re-organization, which sometimes includes jobs going over seas.
Advice to Management
Fire dumb people including yourselves and hire effective people. Pay us more and fix the promotion system. Stop outsourcing American jobs to India and Singapore. Keep the good work life balance and workplace enviroment.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
Fire dumb people including yourselves and hire effective people. Pay us more and fix the promotion system. Stop outsourcing American jobs to India and Singapore. Keep the good work life balance and workplace enviroment.
Helpfu

review_title: Many opportunities to explore, may have to push hard to get them
pros:
Many businesses and roles to explore
Company culture is such that people are always willing to help, explain their role, etc. It's not very competitive/backstabbing culture
Decision making is driven down in the company
Most teams/managers care about the results rather than butts in seats; there is general flexibility around where and when you work
People have a lots of experience to learn from
cons:
Typical with global companies, it's not uncommon to have to work early mornings or late nights, sometimes in the same day. 
The US based sites are on the older side; it can be difficult to move up, very few millennial managers, etc. It's not uncommon to be in your 30s and still be seen as "young."
R&D org is heavily male as you move up in management levels or tech roles
Huge company, which can be difficult to enact change or do it quickly
Company generally funds interesting new projects/products for about 3 years; if not profitable by then it usually is killed off and the team is let go
Advice to Management
Would like to see more women and minorities in the GBU leadership and R&D senior roles. HP needs to figure out how to incubate new ideas in a way where the people working on them aren't all scattered to the wind when HP decides to no longer pursue.

April 26, 2018 – Global Social Media Coordinator
Hi! Thank you for sharing your impressions about working at HP. Responding to your comments about compensation, I want to assure you that we continuously benchmark job and location data for our employment markets in order to offer competitive, market-based pay packages to our employees around the globe. We also give guidelines and training to our managers for administering pay in a way that aligns pay and performance so that employees can share in the success they help create. At HP, total rewards includes more than just your paycheck. It includes a number of programs that fit together. We take the spirit of reinvention to heart, and we continuously review and adjust our total rewards package, including benefits and pay, based on employee feedback and competitiveness. That said, your candid feedback is helpful and appreciated

review_title: Stay away from the inkjet firmware lab
pros:
- At the very top of the company, things seem okay. We have a Chief Diversity Officer (Lesley Slaton Brown) that is very smart and articulate. Catherine Lesjak and Enrique Lores are top notch minds, as far as I can tell. However, they seem really bad at actually getting their middle managers to execute on their vision.
- Work life balance is good on most teams (unless you have to interact with other timezones often).
- Benefits are good by most corporate standards.
- You can be super lazy and still work here for years. Seriously, there are managers making six figures that do literally nothing.
- People care more about being nice than getting work done, which if you are a sandbagger is great.
cons:
- Don't work here if you are a software engineer (embedded or otherwise), they don't value software because almost no one in the management chain has a software background.
- They are always happy to offshore software work to the lowest bidder, and then act surprised when the quality sucks.
- The Inkjet FW lab is a complete shambles. They have hundreds of firmware engineers scattered all over the globe (some who are downright incompetent), a mountain of technical debt, and almost no velocity due to this combination.
- People care more about being nice than getting work done, which is awful if you want to get something done in a dysfunctional organization.
Advice to Management
Clean up the Inkjet FW lab. Stop sending work overseas to the cheapest engineers and/or contracting houses that you can find, you aren't saving any money in the long run. Make sure that all of your engineers at least have a cubicle to do their job in. The office situation in Vancouver is embarrassing.
Helpful (1

pros:
The people at HP Inc. are the reason it's such a great place to work at. People are collaborative and willing to mentor those looking to grow their careers. 

As a worldwide company, there are many opportunities to work with partners all around the world, which leads to opportunities that you just can't get in a smaller firm.

Work-life balance is something that's valued here. There's a gym, a basketball court, a couple of volleyball sand pits, and a soccer field that all get used regularly.

There are strong opportunities to rotate and try new jobs to grow your career. You're not stuck doing one thing forever.
cons:
As with many big companies, sometimes change can be slow. Getting things approved takes longer than it should sometimes.

review_title: HP Corvallis-Engineering Position in HP Print
pros:
The people that I work with are the best part of the job. In general, they are qualified and dedicated. Each division may be different, but those that I have the pleasure of working with are great. I have never had an issue or concern about theft, passive aggressive attitudes, falsification of reports, or anything like that.

Also, there is a great work-life balance. The value on having a life, family, or fun is great. Flexibility to swap a weekday for a weekend is much appreciated. 

Dion does a good job at the highest level of explaining the goals for each quarter, the vision of the future, and relating worldwide accomplishments.
cons:
There is doublespeak about efficiency and quality. It is hard to merge the two ideas together. The timelines for products feel rushed and there is often poor communication between different divisions/departments.
Advice to Management
Improve communication between groups. Improve the onboarding experience by having a better planned training/exposure to the site. Make some decisions more transparent, e.g. hiring, project investment, facilities, etc. Sometimes it feels as though middle management down is waiting for the higher ups to make decisions.

pros: Great work/life balance, great sense of community within sites
cons:
There are many inefficiencies within the company and systems that do not work. There seems to be a disconnect between upper management and most workers. The past year and a half the company has enjoyed lots of growth and profit, none of which has been passed on the the employees There is the extensive use of contract workers instead of using HP employees, even for tasks that are business critical. Promotions are slow to come and are often not accompanied by a raise. Vacations days cannot be rolled over year to year and cannot be cashed out, so younger employees are unable to earn more vacation until they have worked for 5 years. There are very few monetary incentives for work harder, bonuses only come at the end of the year and are fairly small.
Advice to Management
Quit using contract workers for business critical tasks and increase the monetary incentives for your employees to do there best

review_title: Post-separation, HP Inc. is becoming a company worth working for again
pros:
- Telecommuting; flexible work arrangements
- Employees are no longer a number as they were at HP Co.; leadership is beginning to invest again in the workforce/concerned about the employee experience
- Flat-org structures; greater autonomy in work and lots of opportunities
- Great people, ethos, and energy at this company
- Externally, HP products are regaining their reputation and being taken seriously again (particularly in the personal systems space)
- HP is investing in and protecting its future through innovation (particularly with 3D print)
cons:
- Post-separation, resource constraints have put a lot of additional demands on employees (long hours, wearing multiple hats); along these lines, not enough systems/IT people to get the work done
- Though getting better, HP is still lagging to what I've seen in other companies in terms of benefits/pay 
- No time or funds for career advancement/training
- Work/life balance is not the greatest as having lots of very early (6am) or late calls in accommodating all the different time zones
Advice to Management
- Fix resource issues; OD&S post-separation has left us short handed
- Thank you for valuing employees again by improving benefits/pay and the employee experience; keep it up!

review_title: Great place to develop professional skills and seek out new challenges
pros: Excellent learning and professional growth opportunities if you are self motivated, competitive and take the initiative. There are a lot of resources for self-directed learning and job changes to stay challenged. It is possible to stay in the company over 10 years and develop skills in a wide range of functions, geographies, and product divisions.
cons:
There are very few examples of quick advancement or promotions (especially for women), so you need to derive intrinsic satisfaction from the work and the challenge. If you go after and get a higher level job, your salary will generally not be adjusted. You will have to over-achieve to your objectives for many years in order for your salary to catch up to a market value for what you are delivering.
Advice to Management
Outsourcing jobs to 'low cost countries' may not always be a cost savings; we are losing a lot of key talent, there is more strain on the remaining high performers to do more, and it seems like HP is not hiring the highest caliber talent that it used to

The upper management of the sales teams are the most inept, out of touch I've ever seen. RUN. RUN RUN RUN. They want fresh-out-of-college age kids because they can treat them badly and they don't know any better. Sales teams should be treated very well - and are in most companies. HP treats their sales team like dirt, unapologetically. The turn over rate is high - wonder why. And the company parties are pathetic. We will never buy HP products after seeing how this place is managed.

review_title: Not a good place for engineers
pros: People treat each other very well. This culture is protected and promoted. San Diego is a nice place to live.
cons:
Low compensation, after a while I was able to get offers from top tech companies and they were like 2x-3x better. Company looks ridiculously poor, it is a big problem to spend few thousand dollars on hardware and software, management tries to outsource as much as possible to poor countries, benefits are no good, tiny amount of vacations. Holiday parties are lamest that I've seen, they're held in the office and food is not always catered. Very few strong software engineers around, a lot of managers that are completely not qualified in tech, most of them either worked as managers their whole life or have marketing background. I would say that there are some dishonest people in the management as well and they're not going away and even get promoted. Bureaucracy is staggering, IT is a joke (we had like 100Kbs internet connection most of the time) and it is impossible to get anything from IT or HR departments, no amenities in the office, cafeteria is really bad (it was improved after renovation, but it is still pretty bad). In innovation departments work/life balance is pretty bad as well, you will need to work very hard to make something from that little that company is providing you with.
Advice to Management
Currently HP is in the negative feedback loop. Engineering achievements are not rewarded, company loosing good people and becoming even less attractive. Maybe that's fine if HP wants to become entirely branding and distribution company. But in this case I encourage engineers to seek better place to work.

pros:
Very nice physical work environment
Tolerant corporate culture, accepting of all colors, creeds, and orientations
cons:
Relatively low pay. Raises are rare and small, with performance being rewarded occasionally with the possibility of annual discretionary bonuses the amount of which depend on business conditions and management's whims. I saw my workload increase every year as people would be let go and not replaced with their duties just heaped upon the remaining workers.

Huge amount of office politics. The different business units do not co-operate and act like separate companies often in conflict. When making decisions like supply chains or data systems the overall good of HP rarely mattered, only the effects on their own business unit were considered by the business unit's management. 

Lack of C-Level leadership. No vision. Seemingly countless expensive and ultimately pointless, money losing acquisitions (Palm $1.2B, 3com $2.7B, EDS $13.9B, Autonomy $11B). HP culture is ossified, slow to respond, and resistant to change
Advice to Management
Sell the company and call it a day. HP will never be the innovative force it once was, it is too slow to play catch up, and it's only a matter of time until it's broken into bits and sold off. Sad ending for the Grandfather of Silicon Valley

employee_status: Section Manager in San Diego, CA
review_title: I'm still running HP Inc in my veins
pros: Great company, great products, outstanding work environment and nice management team to work for. Great place to get personal development. Highly innovative, world class technical level and most of all extremely talented people.
cons:
Too slow on taking action and making changes. Managers take long time to modify their approach. When HP rolled out eliminating ranking or rating the middle management adopt it on paper but found ways to rate people on ordinal manner and still asked for forcing bottom performers. There will always be a bottom performer even if you build a dream team of previous high performers. These people become a target for getting laid off instead of instead of letting people go because their skill is no longer needed, they are a true low performer, or cost reduction. I left accepting a very good job offer and an amazing challenge otherwise I would gladly still be working at HP.
Advice to Management
Keep it up! HP Inc is really getting reinvented. Nice job!
Need to create more career opportunities at San Diego site.

pros: Overall good culture. and good, hard work, long hours, and the temptation in some groups for folks to not take vacations. Good rules and procedures and people, but inconsistent application. cons:

Advice to Management
Ensure complete background and ethics checks on all employees, not just on paper, but also social media and affiliations. Intake forms do not represent the full picture of typical, creative workers and might miss something critical that can be addressed up-front which can create surprises later. Then, check causes for turnover, especially terminations. Do independent reviews of all cases, including exit interviews where possible, and correct hiring/intake processes.

I worked at HP Inc. full-time for less than a year
Pros

Cons

There are a million different roles at HP and no one to help guide you to the one that best fits you. Employee success must be guided my management.

pros: Fair pay, not high or low. Functions at the facilities, mainly put on and organized by employees, but the company does add some to it. Can sometimes work from home, but this is largely used to get 12-16 hours a day and weekends out of people.
cons:
The running joke at HPI among thousands of employees is, "The work / life balance is that work is your life now. That's the balance". Prepare for required overtime, required working on Veterans Day (even if on a Saturday or Sunday), required working every single day straight for 19 days in November including Saturdays and Sundays in many departments (although not all). It's not a one time event, they actually plan to do this every single year. If you do not work overtime, you cannot keep up with workloads as they purposely plan to give more work than employees can do in 40 hours. Required working through vacations! Even on vacation, most positions it's required to check and respond to emails, even do file work for your position. I have never once had a real vacation off and a couple of them turned into regular 12 hour working days that I never even got to see my family except at dinner. Very strong political views. During the election I received more emails from executives about how evil and awful one side was than I did about HPI. It was depressing that I had to be bombarded at work constantly.
Advice to Management
Stop the lip service and actually try to achieve a real work/life balance. You say words, but you don't follow up with any management to ensure they actually are doing this. Either that or you are aware and are fully complicit. Many employees feel the "culture and values" of old HP are dead and the new HPI just says repeats them but has no intention of following them.

pros: Good benefits and company discounts. We were acquired, so hard to distinguish between our companies benefits vs HP, although they did not change in any negative way. The Sunnyvale, Moffett location has an AMAZING gym. The company is so large, there are many opportunities for growth and experiences.
cons:
We had an outstanding company that was acquired by HP. We watched sales actually go down with their bloated and bureaucratic style of doing business. To be fair, we were a mid-sized, scrappy company, so some reduction in speed would be expected. But we also saw a lot of needless delay and disinterest in the things that our company got right. Don't buy small, profitable companies if you don't know what do do with them... My sentiment has been confirmed recently, as this company was sold off from HP several months ago. We all benefited from the sale, but it's sad to see that HP had no idea with what to do with the exceptional technology and model our company had created.
Advice to Management
HP is bloated and lacks focus! From what I understand, they have recently decided to sell off parts of the company. A smart move that is long overdue.

pros: It's a respectful work culture. The people are nice and want to do the right thing all of the time. There's flexibility in work hours and locations. The technical work is interesting.
cons:
Working at HP is like trying to swim in molasses. No matter how urgent or important a task is, internal processes thwart basic execution. Strategic vision (beyond 3D) is lacking. Executive leadership has very little structure to their decision-making, leading to a combination of rash, emotional risk-taking and terror-driven risk-avoidance. Getting things done requires hiding projects until finished and then delivering a value bomb at the end. That being said, they will probably keep chugging along for years to come from momentum.
Advice to Management
Tighten up decision-making processes at the top in hopes of making better business and technology choices. Give line managers and GMs more flexibility to control their budgets and make investments. Listen to your technologists. Fix broken systems, especially indirect procurement.

review_title: It's a good time to be at HP
pros:
Ever since the HP/HPE split, I've seen a focus at HP that I haven't seen in 15 years. For the first time, there is a strong identity and razor-sharp focus on core strengths in the PC, Print, and Solutions businesses. The result is the strongest product portfolio I've ever seen from HP and the freedom from having to be all things to all customers.

HP has a great legacy in the industry and Silicon Valley. It treats employees and customers with honesty and respect. It's a company that you can take pride in working for.
cons:
The famous "HP Way" culture has largely disappeared. The current culture isn't bad, just bland.

Highly consensus-driven culture means lots of meetings and difficulty making decisions. 

Many product/projects are split between multiple teams and/or business units. In some cases, you have to go all the way to a senior VP or even the CEO to find a single executive with end-to-end authority. This can slow decisions and lead to misaligned incentives between teams.
Advice to Management
Look at organization structures that align incentives and push authority and decision making down the organization. Adopt the technologies and modern workplace practices you espouse to customers.
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: Look at organization structures that align incentives and push authority and decision making down the organization. Adopt the technologies and modern workplace practices you espouse to customers.

pros: Good work/life balance, flexible work hours, ability to work from home if needed, good people, some interesting products, reasonable environment.
cons:
Last quarter the company returned all free cash flow in dividends and buybacks. That does not leave much for R&D. 
Pay bands in my BU are very misleading because even average folks earn less than average pay. Mgmt says that is the norm. Overall pay seems a bit lower than the industry.
Currently compressing folks into smaller cubes with short walls and small group spaces to be more inviting to younger employees is the claim. Employees are expecting high noise levels that will reduce productivity. 
Selling company property and leasing back space to raise cash - San Diego, Boise, Dublin.
Was handed a pile of debt when split between HP and Hewlett-Packard Enterprise.
San Diego site may be gone in 5 - 7 years.

We get nothing from stockholders. We do not buy companies with stock and the stock bought on the market does not pump money into HP. review_title: HP rockets straight to the middle and expects the same from you
pros: If you are less experienced, it is a great place to up your skills and make a decent wage. There are average to good benefits. The people are all pretty great.
cons:
They don't pay unfairly, as in the better performers are not rewarded, so they tend to hemorrhage the all star players. This can be good for those early in their career though.
Advice to Management
Don't limit your pay bands to the average of the area. It's a model for mediocrity. Also, stop calling yourself a startup. Just because you split a year ago, does not make you a start up. You have a lot of enterprise baggage to work through.
